sub_topic: Solving partial differential equations using finite element methods
message_1:
Consider the following partial differential equation: 

$\frac{\partial u}{\partial t}=\frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial x^2}$

Subject to the following initial and boundary conditions: 

$u(x,0)=\sin(\pi x)$

$u(0,t)=u(1,t)=0$

Using a finite element method with $N = 5$ equally spaced nodes for $x \in [0,1]$, determine the numerical solution $u(x,t)$ at time $t = 0.1$.
message_2:
To solve the given partial differential equation (PDE) using the finite element method with N = 5 equally spaced nodes, we first need to discretize the spatial domain and create a mesh. Since we have N = 5 nodes, we will have 4 equally spaced elements. The nodes will be at x = 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, and 1.

Next, we define the linear basis functions (also known as shape functions) for each element. Let $\phi_i(x)$ be the basis function associated with node i. The basis functions are defined as:

$\phi_1(x) = \begin{cases} 
      4x & 0 \le x \le 0.25 \\
      0 & \text{otherwise}
   \end{cases}$

$\phi_2(x) = \begin{cases} 
      4(0.25 - x) & 0 \le x \le 0.25 \\
      4(x - 0.5) & 0.25 \le x \le 0.5 \\
      0 & \text{otherwise}
   \end{cases}$

$\phi_3(x) = \begin{cases} 
      4(0.5 - x) & 0.25 \le x \le 0.5 \\
      4(x - 0.75) & 0.5 \le x \le 0.75 \\
      0 & \text{otherwise}
   \end{cases}$

$\phi_4(x) = \begin{cases} 
      4(1 - x) & 0.75 \le x \le 1 \\
      0 & \text{otherwise}
   \end{cases}$

Now, we approximate the solution u(x,t) as a linear combination of the basis functions:

$u(x,t) \approx \sum_{i=1}^{4} c_i(t) \phi_i(x)$

Substitute this approximation into the PDE and apply the Galerkin method to obtain a system of ordinary differential equations (ODEs) for the coefficients $c_i(t)$. The resulting ODEs are:

$\frac{d c_1}{d t} = \frac{16}{3} (c_2 - c_1)$

$\frac{d c_2}{d t} = \frac{16}{3} (c_1 - 2c_2 + c_3)$

$\frac{d c_3}{d t} = \frac{16}{3} (c_2 - 2c_3 + c_4)$

$\frac{d c_4}{d t} = \frac{16}{3} (c_3 - c_4)$

The initial conditions for the coefficients are given by:

$c_i(0) = \int_{0}^{1} \sin(\pi x) \phi_i(x) dx$

Solving these integrals, we get:

$c_1(0) = \frac{8}{\pi^2} (1 - \cos(\pi/4))$

$c_2(0) = \frac{8}{\pi^2} (\cos(\pi/4) - \cos(\pi/2))$

$c_3(0) = \frac{8}{\pi^2} (\cos(\pi/2) - \cos(3\pi/4))$

$c_4(0) = \frac{8}{\pi^2} (\cos(3\pi/4) - 1)$

Now, we can solve the system of ODEs using a numerical method, such as the forward Euler method, with a small time step (e.g., $\Delta t = 0.01$) until we reach the desired time $t = 0.1$. After solving the ODEs, we can compute the numerical solution $u(x,0.1)$ using the approximation:

$u(x,0.1) \approx \sum_{i=1}^{4} c_i(0.1) \phi_i(x)$
